skill.name: ffind
skill.description: Advanced file finder with type detection and filesystem extraction for analyzing firmware and extracting embedded filesystems. Use when you need to analyze firmware files, identify file types, or extract ext2/3/4 or F2FS filesystems.
skill.summary: Advanced file finder with type detection and filesystem extraction for analyzing firmware and extrac...
skill.author: BrownFineSecurity

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and usage instructions. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, and no external command execution within the skill itself.

content.value_statement: Security researchers need to identify file types and extract embedded filesystems from firmware images. This skill provides commands and guidance for using ffind to analyze binary files, detect file types, and extract ext2/3/4 or F2FS filesystems.
actual_capabilities: Identify file types within firmware and binary images
Extract ext2, ext3, and ext4 filesystems from firmware
Extract F2FS filesystems from firmware images
Analyze multiple files in a single command
Output results in text, JSON, or quiet formats
limitations: Requires ffind binary from iothackbot repository
Requires sudo privileges for filesystem extraction
Requires external tools: e2fsprogs, f2fs-tools, util-linux
Cannot extract encrypted or corrupted filesystems

use_cases.title: Extract filesystems from IoT firmware
use_cases.description: Pull embedded filesystems from IoT device firmware for vulnerability research and reverse engineering

use_cases.title: Analyze firmware composition
use_cases.description: Identify file types and structure within firmware binaries before extraction or modification

use_cases.title: Investigate compromised devices
use_cases.description: Examine firmware images from compromised devices to understand attack surface and malware presence

prompt_templates.title: Basic firmware analysis
prompt_templates.scenario: Analyze a firmware file for file types
prompt_templates.prompt: Use ffind to analyze the firmware image at /path/to/firmware.bin. Show me what file types are embedded and summarize the findings.

prompt_templates.title: Extract all filesystems
prompt_templates.prompt: Run ffind with extraction enabled to pull all embedded filesystems from /path/to/firmware.bin. Use sudo and output to /tmp/analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-file analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze multiple firmware files (file1.bin, file2.bin, file3.bin) and show all file types found in each. Output in JSON format for easy parsing.

prompt_templates.title: Verbose analysis with extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a verbose analysis of the firmware at /firmware/device.bin, extract all filesystems, and save to /results/extracted. Show all detected file types including common formats.

output_examples.input: Analyze the firmware file at /tmp/firmware.bin and extract any embedded filesystems

best_practices: Always use a dedicated analysis directory to prevent accidental overwriting of system files
Run extraction with sudo only when necessary and in non-production environments
Document the firmware version and source device before analysis begins
anti_patterns: Running extraction without first analyzing the file structure
Extracting to system directories like /home or /var without specifying a custom output path
Assuming all file types will be detected without using the -a flag for comprehensive scanning

faq.question: What file systems can ffind extract?
faq.answer: ffind supports ext2, ext3, ext4, and F2FS filesystems. Other formats require different tools.

faq.question: Do I need special permissions for extraction?
faq.answer: Yes, filesystem extraction requires sudo privileges to mount and read the extracted images.

faq.question: Can this skill analyze encrypted firmware?
faq.answer: ffind identifies file types but cannot extract encrypted filesystems without decryption keys.

faq.question: What output formats are available?
faq.answer: Three formats: text (default, human-readable with colors), JSON (machine-readable), and quiet (minimal output).

faq.question: Is my data safe during analysis?
faq.answer: The skill only provides instructions. The ffind tool reads files but does not modify source firmware images.

faq.question: How is ffind different from binwalk?
faq.answer: ffind focuses on filesystem extraction with simpler syntax, while binwalk offers broader entropy analysis and signature scanning.
